title: 115_hr1574
content: The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" is aimed at viewpoint protection, specifically actions by the FCC under Title I of the Communications Act of 1934. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the FCC from taking action against individuals based on their viewpoints on public issues in broadcast content. It also prevents the FCC from imposing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews under certain sections of the Communications Act. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the FCC from taking action against individuals based on their viewpoints in broadcast content. It also prevents the FCC from imposing conditions on approvals related to violations of specific sections of the Communications Act. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the FCC from taking action against individuals based on their viewpoints in broadcast content, including violations of specific sections of the Communications Act. It also covers public interest obligations and incitement under the First Amendment. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the President from directing agencies to take action against individuals based on their viewpoints in broadcast content, including incitement under the First Amendment. This includes not placing conditions on approvals or decisions related to viewpoints. The President is prohibited from directing agencies to place conditions on approvals or decisions related to viewpoints in broadcast content under the "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017." This does not affect the President's authority to take action based on violations. The President cannot direct agencies to impose conditions on approvals or decisions related to viewpoints in broadcast content under the "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017." This does not limit the President's authority to take action based on violations of specific sections of the United States Code. The term "agency" in this subsection refers to its definition in section 551 of the United States Code, and it outlines restrictions on the President's ability to direct agencies regarding broadcast content and incitement under the First Amendment. The term "agency" in this subsection refers to its definition in section 551 of title 5, United States Code, and pertains to the President's duties under the law.
